description: From Anglo-Norman entremedler (= Old French entremesler), from inter- + medler.

verbs.description: intermeddle (third-person singular simple present intermeddles, present participle intermeddling, simple past and past participle intermeddled)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To mix, mingle together. [14th–18th c.]
(obsolete, reflexive) To get mixed up (with). [15th–17th c.]
(intransitive) To butt in, to interfere in or with. [from 15th c.]
